description: Graffiti, rotting wood, baldy patched play equipment: For years now the play area at st norberts green has been neglected. The equipment has been poorly patched up with wood that is now disintegrating and the main structures are rotting too due to lack of maintenance. There is graffiti on many of the wooden parts. The cover on the spring of the elephant is coming away. The noughts and crosses spinners are broken. It would be brilliant for this great little park to be made safe!

interface_used: Heavy electric buses are making our houses shake: Neighbours up and down the whole length of Sprules Road, ourselves included (at number 3), are complaining about our houses jolting and shaking violently whenever the new exceedingly heavy electric buses hit the speed bumps. Some of the driver go a little slower and the jolt is less noticeable but many hit the bumps without slowing and our houses jump as they do. Many neighbours have noticed new cracks and damage since the electric buses arrived in March 2021. We are all worrying about damage to the fascias, walls, and possibly even subsidence if the problem isn‚Äôt solved. The council is passing the buck to TfL. TfL apparently don‚Äôt accept that buses can damage houses üôÑ The bus company have apparently however asked drivers to drive slower, but as stated many of them hit the bumps at speed. A solution might be to cut grooves in the speed bumps to accommodate the buses‚Äô wheels, or to re-route the bus route (though that could inconvenience the school), but something more than driver education needs to be done.

title: open

Many neighbours have noticed new cracks and damage since the electric buses arrived in March 2021. We are all worrying about damage to the fascias, walls, and possibly even subsidence if the problem isn‚Äôt solved. The council is passing the buck to TfL. TfL apparently don‚Äôt accept that buses can damage houses üôÑ The bus company have apparently however asked drivers to drive slower, but as stated many of them hit the bumps at speed. media_url:
Bridge over the River Quaggy: The bridge over the River Quaggy is on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich with Bromley being the highway authority for the bridge and to the east of the bridge. West of the bridge Lewisham is the highway authority, and north of the bridge Greenwich is the highway authority.

Shown in the picture is the shiny new 10T weight restriction sign installed at Bromley taxpayers' expense to the east of the bridge. There are no weight restriction signs to the north of the bridge (Greenwich) or to the west of the bridge (Lewisham).

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.
updated_datetime:

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.

title: 2021-06-03T15:58:35+01:00
service_request_id: Lewisham‚Äôs crews ALWAYS leaving te bins all over the place when they come for collection, instead of putting them back in their dedicated storage. ALWAYS. So every time it‚Äôs windy or when something falls off the bins it‚Äôs all over in the environment instead of being enclosed. Can someone please come put them back before this yard becomes a dump?! Thank you!
column16: Lewisham‚Äôs crews doing a sloppy job: Lewisham‚Äôs crews ALWAYS leaving te bins all over the place when they come for collection, instead of putting them back in their dedicated storage. ALWAYS. So every time it‚Äôs windy or when something falls off the bins it‚Äôs all over in the environment instead of being enclosed. Can someone please come put them back before this yard becomes a dump?! Thank you!

lat: One of our recycling bins is full again. It was full last Friday. It is the bin for cardboard. We have other two bins but they only have bottle holes which means residents are forced to place recyclables into the normal waste bins. This problem has existed for years and been exacerbated by COVID. It has been documented and reported to Lewisham Council and Pinnacle since March 2020 and neither has done anything to try to fix the problem so recyclables are literally wasted and Lewisham Council does not care and no-one is held to account as both Pinnacle and Lewisham Council point the finger at the other.
service_name: Recycling bin full again: One of our recycling bins is full again. It was full last Friday. It is the bin for cardboard. We have other two bins but they only have bottle holes which means residents are forced to place recyclables into the normal waste bins. This problem has existed for years and been exacerbated by COVID. It has been documented and reported to Lewisham Council and Pinnacle since March 2020 and neither has done anything to try to fix the problem so recyclables are literally wasted and Lewisham Council does not care and no-one is held to account as both Pinnacle and Lewisham Council point the finger at the other.

description:
Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction: For over a year I have documented and reported that our block lacked recycling bin capacity. I have reported this to Pinnacle, Regenter and Lewisham Council and none have taken any action to resolve this, they just put the finger at the other.

Two of our recycling bins are full again. One (the cardboard bin) has been full for a week, the other (bottle) for a few days. The third bin with bottle slots may only be partially used so residents have no choice but to put cardboard and other items in the normal waste bins.

Because of Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's ongoing neglect approx 25-30% of our recyclables have been placed in the wrong bins for over a year. Neither care about this and apparently no-one is accountable.

It is beyond incompetence and just a waste of tax payers money - Lewisham Council;

requested_datetime: Large orange gas bottle fly tipped onto pavement by resident of either 38 or 38a holdenby road
title: open
service_request_id:
A Large orange Gas Bottle has been put out onto pavement by residents of either number 38 or 38A Holdenby Road:

I reported the situation of residents at 38 and 38A leaving their Bins outside their properties obstructing the pavement for many days at a time and Fly tipping unwanted household items on the pavement outside their homes on the 3rd of May but evidently Lewisham Council have still not contacted them to instruct them to stop doing that as it is still happening:

Today - Monday 17th May some of the Bins have been left out [again] on the pavement since last Wednesday`s Bin emptying day.

They regularly leave either all 4 Bins or 2 of them out obstructing the pavement for many days - often more than a week.

I originally posted a report about that because it was obstructing the pavement when I was going past with my child`s buggy especially when other people were trying to walk past the bins - I sometimes have had to go out into the road to wait for people to pass the bins before proceeding - not desirable with a child in a buggy.

At no point since I reported this problem 12 days ago have all of the bins been put back onto the residents property / removed from the pavement.

Now one of the residents has put a large orange coloured Gas bottle outside on the pavement.

I wonder if there is still Gas in the bottle ?

I feel that this could be very dangerous if for example an inquisitive child tried to turn it on not realising that they should not touch it.

It is NOT good enough for the Council to just categorise this report / complaint as something like: `Passed to the Highways Department` - I cannot remember the exact term used for my previous report.

title: Missed recycling collection again and overflowing bins
[object Object]
service_request_id: Recycling bins not collected again: For over a year Lewisham Council has failed to consistently collect the recycling bins for this Regenter (Pinnacle) managed block. Documented complaints have been made to both but still no action has been taken. Our bins were full before Easter and were not emptied this week so again residents have to use the normal waste bins to dispose of recyclables. Lewisham Council's contractors do not have the capacity to manage and deliver this contract to the required collection frequency and the estate does not have enough bins to cope with increased bin pressures due to COVID behavioural changes. The bins have not been contaminated but regardless of the evidence this seems to be the Council's go to excuse for not have enough refuse collecting capacity.

agency_sent_datetime: Dangerous car parking on corner near Co-op
status: Cars are parking vertically on the corner of Stanstead Road and Rockbourn Road & obstruct the left view of motorists emerging from Rockbourn Road causing them to get into the centre of the road. Personally had three near accidents at that point because of this. Cars are parked outside the new Co-op so cars heading towards the 205 from Stanstead Road are already overtaking parked cars at that point and meet any vehicle emerging from Rockbourn Road. This issue has been reported to the local Councillor and has been an issue for many months.

media_url:
There is a very large and overgrown tree outside 77 Lewisham Way, which overhangs the pavement and neighbouring property. This tree has never been pruned or inspected and poses a significant potential danger to passers by.

Large branches have been coming off the tree and falling onto the ground and whenever there are winds the tree sways violently.

In addition, the fence next to the tree is damaged and seems to have collapsed - leaving several rusty nails exposed and a large piece of rusted metal grating with branches sticking out of it.

media_url:
Problem not fixed: Stones in Calmont Road: Despite numerous responses today that the problem is fixed, it isn't.

Whilst most stones are not on the Calmont Road carriageway, they are on the Hillbrow Road carriageway. As the photos show, road markings indicating a bump in the road are partially covered and the direct route used by pedestrians crossing Hillbrow is covered by stones. These are particularly difficult to walk on for those in 'equality' categories eg the elderly, infirm and carers with prams. Further more, because the stones are in very close proximity to Calmont Road (and generally are all over it), this is dangerous for cyclists and in addition, car wheels can flick the stones into the air dangerously.
